name: Icelandic Seal Center (Selasetur Íslands)
description: The Icelandic Seal Center in Hvammstangi stands as Iceland's premier institution dedicated to seal education, research, and conservation, combining award-winning museum exhibits with regional tourist information services in a facility overlooking Miðfjörður bay—one of Iceland's most important seal habitats where both harbor seals and gray seals can regularly be observed from shore. Located in Northwest Iceland's remote Húnaþing vestra region, the center provides comprehensive information about the two seal species that inhabit Icelandic waters year-round: harbor seals (Phoca vitulina), smaller and more numerous, preferring sheltered bays and fjords where they haul out on rocks and beaches; and gray seals (Halichoerus grypus), larger and less common, favoring more exposed coastal areas and offshore islands. The center's permanent exhibitions explore seal biology, behavior, life cycles, and adaptations that allow these marine mammals to thrive in Iceland's cold waters—including thick blubber layers providing insulation and energy reserves, physiological adaptations for deep diving and extended breath-holding, excellent underwater vision and hearing, and remarkably efficient swimming capabilities.
